annotation.TEXT: There is one thing to keep in mind about this, however. If you try to edit your chip folder while playing as MegaMan.EXE, any chips you have selected will be sent back to the folder immediately (the game warns you about this beforehand, thankfully). Additionally, this will also reset your extra chip count, making you start off with 5 chips again.

GutsMan.EXE is just as much of a pain as FireMan.EXE, and for one reason: The speed of his "Ground Crusher" move is way faster than it has any right to be (not to mention it deals a ton of damage at this point). Other than that, he has a slow jump that causes a shockwave when he lands (which can stun you for an incredibly long time), and he also has a very fast punch if you get too close to him.

The main reason I bought Bronze Fist will become clear at the beginning of the next segment. For now, while I could buy more HP Memories and other stat-up's, I wanted to conserve my zenny for something else (then again, I'll be grinding for more money eventually).
>Missing the last chip needed to make the Life Sword PA before the boss fight >I will GRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR

The Dash chip can be used to get to several hidden or generally tough-to-reach areas in this game. Notably, it also makes you immune to spikes while in use. This trait will be important for an optional section later on.

Something I didn't have time to mention in the first video was the ability to get more than the usual 5 chips in your selection screen. You actually don't have to pick every chip when prompted to (the one exception to this is the tutorial at the start of the game, which forces you to pick 5 chips). For how many chip slots you leave open, you'll actually get back that amount in extra chips the next time your custom bar fills up. For example, say you only select 3 chips (like how I did here). Since you left 2 potential chip slots open, you'll get 2 extra chips to pick from.

As a side-note: Every battle chip in this game has a limit on how many times you can use them. Collecting a chip either through buying it or as a drop from enemies will increase the chip's use count by 1, but eventually it'll hit its limit. In the case of most Navi chips, their max limit is generally 5 (although there are two Navi chips later on that only have a single use each, but I'll get to those when they become relevant).
^ The raddest Net Navi ever, right here.

Before moving on with the rest of the game, there's something I wanted to mention about the boss fights. Bosses in this game can actually drop two different chips when you beat them: An ability chip, and a Navi chip. The ability chips are just that - they're usually something related to one of the boss' attacks. Meanwhile, Navi chips actually summon the boss to use a completely different attack (although this is subverted with FireMan.EXE, as both his ability and Navi chips act almost identical for some reason).

Yup, immediately ignore those directions and go to the top of this area. You'll be able to find two extra items in doing so, but you won't be able to progress past that point (due to a security cube that you won't be able to open just yet).

Just to note: You'll always get a Navi's ability chip the first time you beat them in the main story. Afterwards, they can drop their Navi chip in the boss re-fight simulator. Getting the Navi chip to drop mostly depends on your ranking. After beating a boss, you'll be given a score for your fight (1 to 10, and then S for the highest possible rank). From what I can tell, getting a high rank mainly stems from beating the boss quickly and taking very little damage in the process. Then again, you don't have to get the best possible score to obtain the Navi chip (they seem to drop anywhere between ranks 8 to S).
